courseDescription: An interdisciplinary examination of the African American experience in America.  The course examines the historical and contemporary conditions of African American people.  It also explores the various modes of artistic expression, values and philosophical underpinnings of African American culture.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in historical data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interdisciplinary communication with scholars and experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical texts and primary sources
Comparative analysis of African American experiences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Facilitating group discussions on complex topics

courseDescription: This course offers students a critical approach to interpreting the history of Africa. A fast-paced survey of African history, it affords students a grounding in the major themes of African history. The course focuses on the major economic, social, and political institutions of Africa, past and present, and explores how historical developments assist comprehension of present-day Africa.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on historical research projects

courseDescription: Required of all history and secondary education social studies majors. Recommended prior to upper-division course work. Examines methods of historical research and primary and secondary source analysis, inclusive of internet usage. Explores historiography and historical writing. Introduces students to issues in the philosophy of history.
Covers the design and implementation of quantitative and qualitative methods of inquiry in social sciences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis techniques in social sciences

courseTitle: Human Rights and Social Change in Africa
courseDescription: This course examines historical social movements in Africa such as economic, ethnic, women's, political, and religious social movements.  This course will also link micro-level, meso-level, and macro-level implications for the social structures and cultures of various African nations and communities.

This course is intended to familiarize students with the struggles, advances, and setbacks of African peoples for state-building and socioeconomic development during the colonial and post-independence eras.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding colonial and post-independence African history
Utilizing online archives for research purposes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex historical information in a clear and engaging manner
Participating in group discussions on sensitive topics
Respecting diverse perspectives in class debates
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critically evaluating historical sources for bias and reliability
Identifying patterns and trends in African political history
Drawing connections between historical events and current political situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively to complete research projects
Leading group projects on African political topics
Collaborating with peers to organize study groups or research initiatives

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to social research methods.  The primary purpose of this course is to survey the major research designs and research techniques that are the core of contemporary approaches used to study social phenomena as well as the lives and experiences of African Americans.  Ethical implications of social research and data analysis will also be covered.

Examination and explanation of minority families' lives in relationship to other societal institutions and historical developments. The course focuses on issues of minority families and places these issues in a sociological framework, e.g., stratification, poverty and gender.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in sociological data collection
Statistical analysis for minority family studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting findings in a clear and concise manner
Engaging in discussions on sensitive topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of minority family issues
Identifying patterns in societal trends affecting minority families
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects on minority family research
Organizing and managing data related to minority family studies

courseDescription: The course examines African-American history from the African background through the Civil War. Emphasis is placed on an analysis of African-Americans' role in the political, economic, social and cultural life of the United States.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital research methods for historical data analysis
Understanding historical databases and digital repositories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of historical research findings
Collaboration with peers on historical research projects
Interacting with diverse perspectives on historical interpretations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical sources and texts
Identifying patterns in historical data for interpretation
Developing research questions and hypotheses in historical context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing historical research projects and timelines
Coordinating group research efforts in historical studies
Taking initiative in exploring underrepresented historical narratives

courseDescription: Individual practical experience in community-based organizations, public bureaucracies, administrative agencies and other organizations and firms.  Student can gain exposure in the not-for-profit and profit sectors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Exposure to not-for-profit and profit sectors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills in navigating bureaucratic systems

courseDescription: This course surveys the political, social and cultural history of colonial and post-independent Africa. Major themes include colonization and resistance, anti-colonial movements, social and cultural transformations, urbanization and popular culture and post colonial challenges.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of colonial and post-colonial political systems in Africa
Digital research skills for historical analysis
Data visualization of historical trends in Africa
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of historical research findings
Collaboration with peers on group projects related to African history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of colonial and post-colonial documents and narratives
Identification of social and cultural transformations in Africa throughout the 20th century
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex historical topics related to Africa
Organizing research materials and sources for academic projects on African history

courseDescription: These courses are open to majors and non-majors.  Ethnic studies majors may take these courses to satisfy requirements for the concentration.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in African American history
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Engaging in discussions on African American history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing research questions in African American studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for research tasks

courseDescription: These courses are open to majors and non-majors.  Ethnic studies majors may take these courses to satisfy requirements for the concentration.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Politics of the Civil Rights Movement
courseDescription: Examines the political activities which resulted in the passage of the nation's second Civil Rights policy, the 1960 and 1964 Civil Rights Acts, the 1965 Voting Rights Act and the 1968 Fair Housing Act. The course will analyze the underpinnings, leadership, and political strategies of the Civil Rights Movement.

courseTitle: African American Political and Social Thought
courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the historical and contemporary experiences of “Blackness” as it has been constructed, contested and affirmed in various historical, political and narrative contexts.  Embracing the theme of duality, the course examines what it means for a culture and people to be both integral to and excluded from the American political and social community. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in historical and contemporary contexts
Writing skills for analysis and reflection
Critical evaluation of political and social narratives
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions on sensitive topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing complex historical and political information
Identifying and addressing dualities in cultural narratives

courseDescription: The study of the process of and responses to the oppression of racial, religious, ethnic, and national minorities in a variety of countries within a historical and comparative perspective. Special emphasis given to American minorities and especially African Americans.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical data on minority oppression
Utilizing GIS mapping software for spatial analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating group discussions on sensitive topics
Addressing conflicts arising from diverse perspectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects on minority rights advocacy
Organizing community engagement events for marginalized groups

courseDescription: This course will examine the intersectionality of race, ethnicity, crime, justice and the operation of the criminal justice system and will critically assess controversial issues surrounding race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. Students will discuss contemporary social justice issues as they relate to race, ethnicity, crime, and justice. The theoretical frameworks that explain the intersection between race, ethnicity, crime and justice will be examined. The course will also investigate the broad range of policy issues and recommendations impacting communities of color and the administration of criminal and social justice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of criminal justice system operations
Theoretical frameworks related to race, ethnicity, crime, and justice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing controversial issues related to race and ethnicity
Engaging in critical analysis of social justice topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of race, ethnicity, crime, and justice intersections
Analyzing policy issues impacting communities of color
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Examining recommendations for criminal and social justice administration

courseDescription: This course examines the impact of diversity, culture, and ethnic origin in criminal justice organizations. The course is designed to better prepare students to meet the challenge of diversity in criminal justice organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of multicultural perspectives in criminal justice
Knowledge of diversity issues in organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing impact of cultural differences on organizational dynamics
Identifying solutions to diversity challenges in criminal justice organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading diverse teams in criminal justice settings

courseDescription: This course examines the issues and perspectives related to the psychological evolution of African Americans in the United States. Particular emphasis is placed on exploring the discipline of psychology from an Afrocentric focus.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse populations in research settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical and current psychological literature on African Americans
Interpreting and applying Afrocentric theories in psychology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex psychological issues related to African Americans
Organizing and facilitating group research projects on African American psychology

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the key concepts involved in developing and executing an interdisciplinary research project.  Students will read and interpret research literature, execute a research project, write a final research paper, and present research findings in a professional setting.

This course focuses on a variety of selected topics in African American Studies.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research skills in African American Studies
Data analysis in African American Studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of African American Studies topics
Research design and methodology in African American Studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in African American Studies research

courseDescription: Students are exposed to opportunities to conduct independent research and/or study in areas focused on the political, social and cultural experiences of people of African descent in the U.S. and the African Diaspora.

courseTitle: Independent Study in Political, Social, and Cultural Experiences of African Descent
courseDescription: Students are exposed to opportunities to conduct independent research and/or study in areas focused on the political, social and cultural experiences of people of African descent in the U.S. and the African Diaspora.
